Earth is our planet. Home to many diverse life forms.
Essential atmospheric gas mixture comprising oxygen, nitrogen & trace elements, vital for respiration & sustaining life
Fire is an intense chemical reaction releasing heat, light, and often flames.
Essential clear liquid sustaining life, comprising of H₂O molecules.
Dispersed soil particles mixed with organic matter typically resulting from erosion or human activity; commonly seen as unclean substance.
The atmosphere is the gaseous layer surrounding Earth, comprising oxygen, nitrogen, water vapor & trace elements essential for life support.
Lava is molten rock erupting from volcanoes or fissures, typically very hot & destructive.
A living organism rooted in soil, producing food via photosynthesis.
Wind is the natural air current resulting from atmospheric pressure differences & horizontal movement of gases.
Visible airborne particulate matter created by burning or combustion.
Atmospheric water vapor condensation visible as a floating mass in the sky.
The region of the atmosphere that is visible from the ground, extending from the horizon to outer space.
Energy transferred due to temperature difference resulting in molecular vibration.
Hot water vapor formed during heat conversion.
A small collection of water, typically formed from rain or melted snow, lying on the ground or other surface.
A mixture of water and soil or other materials, typically containing impurities.
A block of clay hardened by heat for use in construction.
A structure designed to stand up and prevent the passage of people or things such as a barrier constructed of brick, stone, or other material.
A building that functions as living quarters. It typically consists of rooms arranged around a central hall.
A small community having a central place, as a village green.
A small or medium-sized settlement having a defined community and being larger than a village but smaller than a city.
A large and permanent human settlement with an urban design and infrastructure.
A large city, typically one that is a significant cultural, financial, or political center for a nation or region.
A large, enclosed container for burning fuel to produce heat or power.
A heavy, silvery-grey, ductile metal, used for making tools, machinery, and other structural components.
A precious yellow metal, highly malleable and ductile, and not easily corroded or tarnished.
A large perennial plant with a single stem or trunk, supporting branches and leaves in most species.
A small thicket of trees, especially one that forms a copse or woodland.
A large area covered with trees and undergrowth. A forest can be used for various purposes, such as timber, fuel, food, medicines, and recreation.
A large forest covered with undergrowth and tall trees, especially in tropical regions.
A wetland area covered by shallow water and having a spongy surface, typically forested with mosses, rushes, or trees.
A large hot spring, characterized by intermittent eruptions of steam, hot water, or mud.
A spring of thermal water, often located in geothermal areas and typically heated to a temperature above human body temperature.
A body of flowing water moving between land and land, or a narrow, continuous flow of liquid.
A large flowing body of water that usually empties into a sea or ocean.
A large body of still or slowly moving water, larger than a pond, surrounded by land.
A large body of salt water that covers the Earth's surface, not as part of the rivers, lakes, or glaciers.
A large body of salt water that covers most of Earth's surface and supports a variety of aquatic life.
A solid piece of mineral composition, typically one that can be cut and used as a tool or building material.
A large, usually rounded, mass of rock; a boulder.
A large natural elevation of the Earth's surface rising abruptly from the surrounding level.
A series of connected mountains or hill ranges forming a distinct and generally continuous chain.
A piece of sub-continental land surrounded by water.
A large area of land surrounded by water, forming one of the major divisions of the Earth.
A celestial body orbiting a star, large enough to be rounded by its own gravity.
A piece of ground on which plants, buildings, or other structures may stand.
The change of a substance from a gas to a liquid, especially water vapor in the air forming dew or frost.
Large drops of water falling from clouds, often as part of the precipitation process.
A disturbance of the atmosphere characterized by strong winds, heavy rain, thunder, and sometimes hail or snow.
An electric discharge that occurs in the atmosphere, producing a bright flash and thunder.
A flow of electric charge, causing a current to move in a conductor.
Extremely small particles of matter, usually raised into the air and settled as a powder.
A loose, fragmented, naturally occurring mineral material, formed of small, loose grains.
A land area along a body of water that slopes gradually towards the water and is covered with sand, gravel, shingle, or other particles.
A barren area of landscape where little precipitation occurs and, consequently, living conditions are hostile for plant and animal life.
A hard, transparent material, often used to make windows, bottles, or other objects.
A container with a narrow neck and a bulging body, used for storing liquids.
A decorative ball filled with water and small models, which creates a snowy scene when shaken.
A wide-mouthed container with a tight-fitting lid, used for holding or preserving food.
A type of reciprocating prime mover that converts heat energy into mechanical work to create motion.
An instrument, especially one held in the hand, used to carry out a particular function.
A tool consisting of a heavy flat blade fixed in a wooden handle, used for chopping down trees or splitting wood.
A hard, fibrous substance found in the stems and roots of a tree.
A watercraft designed to float or plane, providing transportation or transportation of goods on water.
The powdery residue left after a substance has been burned.
A small fire built outdoors, typically in a portable metal or stone fire pit, used for cooking, warmth, or recreation.
A large flat stone used to cover the grave of a person, often engraved with an inscription.
A place for the burial of the dead, often with trees or shrubs, providing a solemn atmosphere.
Radiant energy, usually visible, that is emitted from a source and travels as electromagnetic waves.
A meteorological phenomenon that is caused by reflection, refraction and dispersion of light in water droplets.
Hard, calcium structures that give support and shape to the body of an animal, protecting vital organs.
The remains or traces of an organism preserved in fossil fuels, petrified wood, or stone since the Precambrian time.
A large reptile that lived in the Mesozoic Era, now extinct, characterized by a bipedal or quadrupedal gait and a large body size.
A legendary creature, typically a large serpent-like or reptile-like entity, capable of breathing fire.
A large watercraft designed for transportation on water, typically with a hull and sails or engines.
A thin material produced by pressing together the pulp of trees or other plants, usually fitting for writing or printing.
A collection of written, printed, illustrated, or blank sheets, made of ink, paper, parchment, or other materials, usually fastened together to hinge at one side.
A primate animal with a long, usually prehensile tail, pointed snout, and opposable thumbs.
An Old World monkey that is considered a primate, with humans being the closest living relatives.
A living organism that is characterized by voluntary movements, a complex nervous system, the ability to reason and communicate, and having a body with five sensory organs.
A reanimated corpse, typically depicted as a decaying body that exhibits a strong desire for human flesh.
A person who robs ships and lives by plundering and pillaging.
Valuable material, especially metals like gold and silver, or gems.
A precious stone, especially one that has been cut and polished.
The part of the head that is covered by the top growth of hair or by a covering such as a crown.
A supposed apparition of a deceased person, believed to inhabit an area or repeatedly appear to living persons.
The framework or structure of a thing, especially a living organism.
The bony, protective structure at the upper end of the spinal column of a vertebrate, containing the brain.
A hard-shelled object from which a baby animal hatches.
A warm-blooded egg-laying vertebrate covered with feathers, with a beaked and often webbed head and limbs adapted for flight.
A group of sheep, especially when tended by a single shepherd.
A group of animals that move together, usually for protection.
A large, showy North American butterfly with orange wings and black veins, and a distinctive white patch on each wing near the tail.
A tall, continuous structure, typically consisting of several vertically stacked floors and often used as a place of residence or business.
A large, imposing building, typically with several floors and surrounded by a moat or high walls.
A large, impressive building, typically having several stories and many rooms, occupied by a monarch or other person of high rank.
A medieval warrior, wearing body armor and mounted on horseback, maintaining peace and justice in a kingdom.
A monarch, or the supreme ruler of a country, state, or other polity.
A female sovereign, monarch, or ruler.
A two-player strategy game played on a checkered board with 16 pieces each, one set white and the other black.
A bladed weapon with a long handle, used for cutting or thrusting.
A professional who designs, builds, or maintains structures, machines, devices, systems, and processes.
A machine, often programmable by a computer, capable of carrying out a complex series of actions automatically.
Someone who grows and harvests crops on a farm.
A black or brownish-black sedimentary rock formed by compacting and indurating of peat and coalified plant matter, containing significant amounts of carbon and hydrocarbons.
The condition that distinguishes physical entities having biological processes, such as growth, reproduction, and response to stimuli, from those lacking such processes.
A sculpture in stone, metal, or other material, usually depicting a person or animal, and often on a pedestal.
A mythical being made of clay or mud, often animated and given the form of a human, giant or animal.
A mineral composed of pure carbon, valued for its beauty and durability.
A block in Minecraft that is as hard as diamond, but has no specific function other than being decorative.
A semi-solid mixture of snow and water, often melted and sweetened to make a dessert.
A solid state of water formed by freezing, typically containing impurities like snowflakes.
A common water crystal that falls as snowflakes in winter weather.
A large piece of fresh glacier ice that has broken off and is floating in the sea.
A small body of still or gently flowing water, especially in a natural or semi-natural setting.
A broad, flat platform on the surface of water, used as a floating base by some aquatic animals.
A cold-blooded aquatic animal. Fish have gills for breathing and fins for swimming.
A substance burnt to produce a fragrant smoke as a religious or aromatic offering.
A small, midge-like fly that can transmit diseases, such as malaria and yellow fever, via its bite.
A large number of animals or insects flying, swimming, or moving together in close formation.
An insect that is covered with fuzzy hair, feeds on nectar and pollen, and makes honey.
A structure made by bees from wax, for storing honey and rearing young.
A sweet food made from the nectar of flowers by bees.
An alcoholic beverage made from fermented honey and water, often with fruits or herbs added for flavor.
The star at the center of the solar system, providing light and heat through its radiation.
The natural satellite that revolves around a planet and is illuminated by sunlight to produce a luminous effect.
A massive celestial body, luminous in the night sky, radiating energy derived from nuclear reactions within its core.
A group of stars forming a recognizable pattern in the night sky.
The sun and all the planets and other celestial bodies that revolve around it.
A system of millions or billions of stars, together with gas and dust, held together by gravitational attraction.
All existing matter, energy, space, and time; the cosmos.
A hypothetical group of multiple universes, including our universe.
A 24-hour period of time, usually beginning at sunrise and ending at sunrise the next day.
The period of darkness between sunset and sunrise.
The soft red, orange, and purple light that occurs when the sun is near the horizon.
A representation of an area of the world, showing physical features, locations, and roads.
An instrument used for determining directions, typically having a dial calibrated with a magnetic compass needle pointing toward magnetic north.
An instrument that measures, displays, and records time.
The continuous passage of existence and events that occurs in the present. In physics, it is the dimension in which events occur and are measured in seconds, minutes, hours, etc.
The three-dimensional expanse in which all physical objects are located and have relation.
The sacred writings of a religion, used as a guide for conduct, religious beliefs, and practices.
A religious leader authorized to perform the sacred rites of a religion, especially the administration of sacraments.
A piece of furniture used for storing and displaying books.
A building or room containing a collection of books, periodicals, and sometimes films, records, or other sources of information.
A group of individuals related by blood or marriage, or those who live together as a close-knit group.
A young human being or other creature in its early stage of development.
A person who attends an educational institution, typically one enrolled in a course or degree program.
An institution providing education, usually for children, in a formal setting.
The act of receiving a degree or diploma, typically at the end of a course of study.
A person who teaches students, typically at a school or university.
A document issued by a college or university upon completion of a course of study.
An activity, particularly a regular occupation, for which someone is employed to perform a service or labour.
A seafaring explorer, raider, or trader from Northern Europe, active mainly from the late 8th to the late 11th centuries.
The enormous tree at the center of the Norse cosmos, uniting the various realms.
An act of supplication directed towards a deity or deities or an expression of hope for help, comfort, and guidance.
An art form employed for the purpose of entertaining, expressing emotion, and communicating.
A building used for public Christian worship.
A set of beliefs, values, and practices that is often institutionalized and is considered to be a cultural system.
The bishop of Rome and leader of the Roman Catholic Church.
The expression or application of human creative skill and imagination, typically in a visual form such as painting or sculpture.
The quality of an object or substance with respect to light reflected or emitted from it, usually determining its appearance.
An electric device producing visible light from an electric current. Most common type is the incandescent bulb.
A thought or suggestion as opposed to a material object.
A mythical creature, often depicted as a horse with a single horn on its forehead.
A watercraft designed to operate underwater, usually propelled by a nuclear engine or battery-powered electric motor.
A motor vehicle designed for transportation on roads, typically having four wheels, a single engine, and seating for several people.
A large motor vehicle designed to carry many passengers, typically on a fixed route.
A type of railway locomotive that generates steam to move its wheels.
A substance that can be burned or otherwise converted into heat, energy, or mechanical work.
A vehicle that runs regularly on rails, used for transporting passengers or goods.
A powered, fixed-wing aircraft, making long-distance air travel possible.
A large balloon that carries passengers aloft by heating the air inside it with a fire.
A precious metal that is a chemical element with the symbol Ag and atomic number 47.
A ductile metal that is an excellent conductor of electricity. It is found as a pure metal and in ores.
